page.title: 02SIDDICK POND
page.content: Siddick Nature Reserve became an official reserve in 1981 and is owned by Allerdale District Council. Over 100 different species of birds visit each year, but only 35 species breed there.The rarest breed to appear is the Osprey, seen about once per year. The commonest birds are the coots and the starlings. The pond,which is about 10 hectares in area,lies in an ancient dried-up bed of the River Derwent, but today is fed by Ling Beck. The water temperature depends on the state of the tide. Nearby is Burrow Walls, thought to be the remains of a Roman coastal signal station. It is situated on the top of a high bank, Oyster Bank,a former sea cliff. The whole site is now overseen by the Nature Conservancy.
